{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2980216,"name":"Scott Rowe, 3512","username":"sandarowe","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/53a042/{size}.png","created_at":"2021-12-06T23:54:53.293Z","cooked":"

Not sure if this is the place for this, but does anyone have a rough estimate of what the breakdown is for teams that use swerve drives in terms of software? Is the majority C, Java, Labview? Is there a clear advantage from one to the other in terms of what has already been developed?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2021-12-06T23:54:53.293Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":65,"reads":262,"readers_count":261,"score":377.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":397887,"topic_slug":"swerve-drive-programming-breakdown","display_username":"Scott Rowe, 3512","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":41593,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/swerve-drive-programming-breakdown/397887/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":2980217,"name":"Chris Gerth","username":"gerthworm","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gerthworm/{size}/268658_2.png","created_at":"2021-12-06T23:59:32.258Z","cooked":"

The largest, least biased source of stats I know of would be the yearly usage data. However, this won’t directly report “swerve drive” or “not swerve drive”.

If you do manage to get data, I’d take it with a grain of salt: Give that swerve could be done in any of the three, what you’d really be measuring is “how does the programming language distribution skew when you down-select to teams with the technical ability to field a swerve drive”.

Is there a specific question you’re looking to answer with the data?

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2021-12-06T23:59:32.258Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":260,"readers_count":259,"score":67.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":397887,"topic_slug":"swerve-drive-programming-breakdown","display_username":"Chris Gerth","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.firstinspires.org/sites/default/files/uploads/resource_library/frc/technical-resources/2020/2020UsageData.xlsx","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":21}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24617,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/swerve-drive-programming-breakdown/397887/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2980218,"name":"Tom Line","username":"Tom_Line","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tom_line/{size}/236809_2.png","created_at":"2021-12-07T00:00:02.653Z","cooked":"

Wpilib has swerve drive commands built in. A number of LabVIEW teams have released full code, and Jim Simpson has released portions of the wpilib for LabVIEW. You really can’t go wrong using a wpilib supported language or LabVIEW.

The biggest thing to remember is that if you haven’t already DONE swerve, trying to do it for the first time in season is a mistake.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2021-12-07T00:00:02.653Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":243,"readers_count":242,"score":73.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":397887,"topic_slug":"swerve-drive-programming-breakdown","display_username":"Tom Line","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7841,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Team 1498"},"post_url":"/t/swerve-drive-programming-breakdown/397887/3","custom_user_title":"Team 1498","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2980223,"name":"Scott Rowe, 3512","username":"sandarowe","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/53a042/{size}.png","created_at":"2021-12-07T00:41:57.132Z","cooked":"

More of a global issue with us. We lost our software mentor and our team has used C the entire time. Not sure if this is a good timeframe (next year, not this year) to go in a different direction since we want to start using swerve drive on a regular basis. We have the test robot done and will probably fully implement swerve drive next summer. Just unsure if what the majority of teams that use swerve tend to utilize one language over the other.20211204_130640|666x500

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2021-12-07T00:41:57.132Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":223,"readers_count":222,"score":64.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":397887,"topic_slug":"swerve-drive-programming-breakdown","display_username":"Scott Rowe, 3512","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"/uploads/short-url/bOqaZCeedJFZTj9Hx37v09lRbOf.jpeg","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":12}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":24617,"username":"gerthworm","name":"Chris Gerth","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gerthworm/{size}/268658_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":41593,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/swerve-drive-programming-breakdown/397887/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2980225,"name":"Brad","username":"Bmongar","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bmongar/{size}/228654_2.png","created_at":"2021-12-07T00:59:30.784Z","cooked":"

You could make a poll.

For what it is worth we will be building our first swerve this Saturday and plan to run Java. This is a trial run before the season to see if we are ready. If we can’t effectively get characterization and autonomous movement before kickoff we will likely pass on swerve this season. If we get it going then it is up to the game design.

Gotcha, I feel for ya! I wish I had a solid answer on what the best approach in your case will be.

The two things I generally advise people in your situation to look into before making a decision:

  1. Do the folks who will be responsible for delivering functional software have a preference, based on their prior experiences?
  2. Is there an existing codebase for your team you wish to keep using, which would influence your decision?

If neither of those questions give clear direction: Pick Java. The reason is “safety in numbers”: The vast majority of FRC teams use it (regardless of drivetrain type), and it will be well supported now and in the future. You’ll have more people who can provide direct help on this forum and on the Discord server.

We use java. It’s easier than c and quicker to code with than LabVIEW. That said, I have been struggling with a swerve chassis my team put together for me to play with for over 5 months (not java’s fault)

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2021-12-08T04:49:07.682Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":130,"readers_count":129,"score":51.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":397887,"topic_slug":"swerve-drive-programming-breakdown","display_username":"Micah Guttman","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":41593,"username":"sandarowe","name":"Scott Rowe, 3512","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/53a042/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":38591,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5892 | Alum"},"post_url":"/t/swerve-drive-programming-breakdown/397887/7","custom_user_title":"5892 | Alum","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2980462,"name":"Brad","username":"Bmongar","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bmongar/{size}/228654_2.png","created_at":"2021-12-08T15:37:16.897Z","cooked":"

All the different classes involved are kicking my butt a little too. Not to mention that different examples seem to use different ways of representing or communicating movement. I should get the drive to play with this weekend. But having autonomous before the season may not be in the cards.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2021-12-08T15:37:16.897Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":8,"reads":117,"readers_count":116,"score":63.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":397887,"topic_slug":"swerve-drive-programming-breakdown","display_username":"Brad","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":38591,"username":"memtech3","name":"Micah Guttman","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/41988e/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":38557,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5126 Codenator / Electrical, CSA, FTAA, Inspector "},"post_url":"/t/swerve-drive-programming-breakdown/397887/8","custom_user_title":"5126 Codenator / Electrical, CSA, FTAA, Inspector ","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2980496,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2021-12-08T17:20:07.718Z","cooked":"

Swerve is not easy. Even with the abstractions provided for you, there are a lot of moving parts and a lot of potential failure points. Make sure you plot as much telemetry as possible, and keep scrupulous track of your units.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2021-12-08T17:20:07.718Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":113,"readers_count":112,"score":47.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":397887,"topic_slug":"swerve-drive-programming-breakdown","display_username":"Eli Barnett","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!"},"post_url":"/t/swerve-drive-programming-breakdown/397887/9","custom_user_title":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2980529,"name":"Tyler Veness","username":"calcmogul","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/calcmogul/{size}/128045_2.png","created_at":"2021-12-08T19:47:41.772Z","cooked":"
gerthworm:

Give that swerve could be done in any of the three, what you’d really be measuring is “how does the programming language distribution skew when you down-select to teams with the technical ability to field a swerve drive”.

Even if swerve is overrepresented by C++ or LabVIEW, I don’t expect that to be the case much longer.

Here’s the historical language marketshare and projections for the next few years for context.

2020-lang-usage-projected1733×753 41.1 KB

I’m always surprised by how linear the trends are. LabVIEW will “die” in 2023 and C++ will “die” in 2024. You’ll still have a few die-hard users of each, and some teams get the NI grant that requires using LabVIEW.

I think this trend will continue not because Java is a good choice for real-time systems like an FRC robot (it’s not), but because it’s a good fit for FRC’s learning environment and userbase*. In the embedded industry, you’d pick something like C or C++ instead. Java is mainly used for web/desktop application and backend development, last time I looked.

* WPILib still implements a lot of the Java features in C++ on the backend for performance reasons. The split between Java and C++ source code is 20:80.
